Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
This projects aims to understand how plant endosomal proteins control the trafficking and degradation of plasma membrane proteins, including receptors, channels, and certain cell wall biosynthetic enzymes. The ESCRTs (Endosomal Sorting Complex Required for Transport) are multimeric protein complexes that specifically recognize and sort those plasma membrane proteins that need to be transported to the vacuole for degradation. The completion of these studies will clarify the functional aspects of the plant endosome system. There is strong evidence suggesting that the organization and function of the plant endosomal system is different from their counterparts in yeast or animals. In fact, plants have endosomal components with no orthologs in other organisms. This project will also analyze the roles of endosomal trafficking in various aspects of plant life, such as development, cell type specification, cell wall remodeling, signal transduction, and hormone transport.

BROADER IMPACTS
The project will have impact on education and outreach. The PI is currently teaching two undergraduate and two graduate courses in the University of Wisconsin. One graduate student from an under-represented group in science is already working on this project. The application of state-of-the-art imaging techniques will be also important for education, since the PI is committed to develop workshops on cell biology and cell imaging for undergraduate and graduate students across campus as part of the educational activities of the Plant Imaging Center in the Department of Botany-University of Wisconsin, which was initially supported by NSF funds. In addition, the PI's group provides confocal and electron tomography images obtained in this study for display at the microscope and imaging discovery niche in the Town Center of the new Wisconsin Institute of Discovery on campus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to understand how cells control the degradation of proteins inserted in their plasma membrane. The plasma membrane completely surrounds the cell content and represents the interphase between the cell and its environment. Proteins located at the plasma membrane are very important to sense hormones and other signals from neighbor cells and from the environment. Cells use complex molecular machineries and organelles to remove specific proteins from the plasma membranes and take them to hydrolytic organelles (vacuoles) for degradation. We focused our analysis of a group of proteins named ESCRTs (Endosomal Sorting Required for Transport) that act on organelles called endosomes selecting the plasma membrane proteins that need to be degraded. By studying plants defective in ESCRT proteins and performing biochemical assays and microscopy imaging studies, we discovered new aspects of this process in plants. We identified a novel ESCRT component that has evolved specifically within plants and that regulates plant growth and development. We also found that ESCRT proteins are important in the degradation of chloroplasts, the organelles where photosynthesis takes place. Finally, by performing 3D structural analysis and implementing mathematical simulations, we have now a much better understanding about how endosomes form and work. 

These results have been disseminated through papers published in peer-reviewed journals and both oral and poster presentation in various scientific conferences.

This project has involved the training of nine undergraduate students at the University of Wisconsin-Madison who has performed experiments and analyzed data in our laboratories, two graduate students, and two postdoctoral fellows.  We have also provided images, movies, and 3D prints of cellular reconstructions to the Wisconsin Institutes for Discovery for display in their microscope and imaging discovery niche in the Town Center. Thus material is used for weekly outreach activities with K-12 students.
